<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 675, 529]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 168, 89]]<|/det|>
## Formulae

decay constant,  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 560, 145]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 526, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 193, 536, 223]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 235, 524, 252]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 262, 571, 295]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V} < c^2 >\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 304, 536, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 338, 608, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 384, 536, 418]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 426, 625, 445]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 459, 593, 478]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 490, 528, 514]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 526, 593, 545]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 560, 625, 579]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 592, 561, 611]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 626, 581, 645]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 655, 536, 688]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 73, 544, 91]]<|/det|>
## Section A  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[298, 102, 700, 121]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 149, 97, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 149, 479, 168]]<|/det|>
Define _gravitational potential_ at a point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 146, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 870, 262]]<|/det|>
The gravitational potential \(\phi\) at distance \(r\) from point mass \(M\) is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 272, 524, 301]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{GM}{r}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 460, 338]]<|/det|>
where \(G\) is the gravitational constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 670, 370]]<|/det|>
Explain the significance of the negative sign in this expression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[851, 444, 875, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 144, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 873, 523]]<|/det|>
A spherical planet may be assumed to be an isolated point mass with its mass concentrated at its centre. A small mass \(m\) is moving near to, and normal to, the surface of the planet. The mass moves away from the planet through a short distance \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 873, 571]]<|/det|>
State and explain why the change in gravitational potential energy \(\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the mass is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 584, 531, 603]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}} = mgh\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 615, 470, 632]]<|/det|>
where \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 800, 875, 819]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 108]]<|/det|>
The planet in **(c)** has mass \(M\) and diameter \(6.8 \times 10^{3} \text{km}\). The product \(G M\) for this planet is \(4.3 \times 10^{13} \text{N} \text{m}^{2} \text{kg}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 118, 875, 168]]<|/det|>
A rock, initially at rest a long distance from the planet, accelerates towards the planet. Assuming that the planet has negligible atmosphere, calculate the speed of the rock as it hits the surface of the planet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 333, 875, 352]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ......................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 333, 875, 351]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 737, 92]]<|/det|>
The kinetic theory of gases is based on some simplifying assumptions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 839, 121]]<|/det|>
The molecules of the gas are assumed to behave as hard elastic identical spheres. State the assumption about ideal gas molecules based on

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 180, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 134, 440, 153]]<|/det|>
the nature of their movement,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 77, 945, 121]]<|/det|>
<form>Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 227, 181, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 227, 304, 245]]<|/det|>
their volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 227, 875, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
A cube of volume \(V\) contains \(N\) molecules of an ideal gas. Each molecule has a component \(c_{\mathrm{X}}\) of velocity normal to one side S of the cube, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 112, 722, 298]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[438, 308, 509, 327]]<|/det|>
<mark>[b]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 337, 875, 357]]<|/det|>
The pressure \(p\) of the gas due to the component \(c_{\chi}\) of velocity is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 365, 534, 386]]<|/det|>
\[pV = Nmc_{\chi}{}^{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 394, 450, 412]]<|/det|>
where \(m\) is the mass of a molecule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 422, 552, 441]]<|/det|>
Explain how the expression leads to the relation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 450, 546, 475]]<|/det|>
\[pV = \frac{1}{3} Nm< c^2>\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 620, 507]]<|/det|>
where \(< c^2>\) is the mean square speed of the molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 675, 876, 692]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 702, 144, 720]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 700, 875, 734]]<|/det|>
The molecules of an ideal gas have a root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of \(520 \text{ m s}^{- 1}\) at a temperature of \(27^{\circ} \text{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 744, 737, 763]]<|/det|>
Calculate the r.m.s. speed of the molecules at a temperature of \(100^{\circ} \text{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 928, 876, 947]]<|/det|>
<form>r.m.s. speed = ............................................ $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[856, 928, 875, 945]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 376, 91]]<|/det|>
Define specific latent heat.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 78, 945, 112]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 109, 873, 128]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 195, 146, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 609, 214]]<|/det|>
The heater in an electric kettle has a power of \(2.40 \text{kW}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 875, 244]]<|/det|>
When the water in the kettle is boiling at a steady rate, the mass of water evaporated in 2.0 minutes is \(106 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 655, 260]]<|/det|>
The specific latent heat of vaporisation of water is \(2260 \text{J} \text{g}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 875, 307]]<|/det|>
Calculate the rate of loss of thermal energy to the surroundings of the kettle during the boiling process.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 473, 875, 492]]<|/det|>
<form>rate of loss = ............................................ $W$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[856, 473, 875, 492]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 875, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 875, 230]]<|/det|>

The sphere has a radius of \(25 \text{cm}\). Electrical breakdown (a spark) occurs in the air surrounding the sphere when the electric field strength at the surface of the sphere exceeds \(1.8 \times 10^4 \text{V cm}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 242, 180, 260]]<|/det|>

<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 722, 92]]<|/det|>
A person is to be investigated using a magnetic resonance (MR) scanner.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[866, 78, 945, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>Examiner's Use</FORM>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 727, 121]]<|/det|>
This technique involves the use of two superimposed magnetic fields.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 584, 139]]<|/det|>
Describe the functions of these two magnetic fields.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 306, 876, 324]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 148, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 333, 875, 369]]<|/det|>
The frequency \(f\) of the electromagnetic waves emitted by protons on relaxation in an MR scanner is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 380, 515, 399]]<|/det|>
\[f = 2cB\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 875, 462]]<|/det|>
where \(B\) is the total magnetic flux density and \(c\) is a constant equal to \(1.34 \times 10^{8} \text{s}^{-1} \text{T}^{-1}\). The magnetic flux density changes by \(2.0 \times 10^{-4} \text{T}\) for each \(1.0 \text{cm}\) thickness of tissue in a section.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 747, 479]]<|/det|>
The scanner is adjusted so that the thickness of each section is \(3.0 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 655, 509]]<|/det|>
Calculate, for corresponding points in neighbouring sections,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 180, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 520, 512, 540]]<|/det|>
the difference in magnetic flux density,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 705, 876, 724]]<|/det|>
<form>difference in flux density = ............................................. T [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 736, 181, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 736, 465, 755]]<|/det|>
the change in emitted frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 920, 876, 939]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency change = ............................................ Hz [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 109, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
In a mobile phone system, the area covered by the system is divided into a number of cells.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 390, 122]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 180, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 134, 618, 153]]<|/det|>
neighbouring cells use different carrier frequencies,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 198, 875, 217]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 227, 181, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 227, 724, 246]]<|/det|>
each cell has a limited area, even in sparsely populated regions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 289, 875, 308]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 319, 146, 338]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 875, 369]]<|/det|>
